G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: Jurisdiction properly lies in the Superior Court Department of the Trial Court of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the acts and omissions alleged herein occurred in Springfield, within the county of Hampden.

*Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006.raw_text: *Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006); Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2000).*
*Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others.
*Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006.support_reasoning: The Jupin opinion explicitly states, as a general principle of Massachusetts tort law, that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, citing Remy v. MacDonald and the Restatement (Second) of Torts. It further ties the existence of that duty to the recognizability or foreseeability of the risk of harm, which matches the proposition that Massachusetts law imposes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others. Thus, the case directly supports the cited general duty principle.
*Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor.”

*See Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 45.raw_text: *See Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mass. 37, 40 (2009).*
*See Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 45.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the maintenance and placement of personal property within the shared driveway area.
*See Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 45.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a hospital owed a duty to a nonpatient police officer to control or detain a sedated patient; it does not involve premises liability or any duty regarding maintenance or placement of personal property in a shared driveway. The court ultimately holds that the hospital owed no duty to the plaintiff in the circumstances presented. Thus, the case neither addresses nor supports the proposition that a defendant owed a duty of reasonable care in maintaining or placing personal property in a shared driveway area.
*See Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 45.relevant_excerpt: “We have not previously recognized, and do not now recognize, a duty to a third person of a medical professional to control a patient (excluding a patient of a mental health professional, see note 10, supra) arising from any claimed special relationship between the medical professional and the patient.… The hospital owed no duty to Leavitt to control or detain the patient.”

*See Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass..raw_text: *See Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739, 743 (1995) (“Foreseeability of harm determines the duty of care.”).*
*See Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass..proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to secure or properly store an inherently unstable, freestanding aluminum ladder in an area exposed to outdoor elements and wind.
*See Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns breach of a premises‑liability duty by improperly storing an unstable ladder; this opinion deals with whether a racetrack owed any duty to provide a pedestrian bridge, traffic signal, or other alterations to a state highway, and with vicarious liability for a police officer’s conduct. The quoted line about foreseeability and duty is not in the provided text, and nothing here addresses storage of equipment, ladders, or similar conditions on land. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the specific ladder‑storage negligence proposition, even though it discusses general duty principles.
*See Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury. … In determining whether the defendant had a duty to be careful, we look to existing social values and customs, as well as to appropriate social policy.” (420 Mass. at 742-743).

*See Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Sa.raw_text: *See Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc., 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901, 902 (1987).*
*See Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Sa.proposition: Defendant’s failure to secure the ladder, despite Plaintiff’s express warnings, constitutes conduct below the standard of a reasonably prudent person under like circumstances.
*See Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Sa.case_name: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.
*See Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Sa.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with a landowner’s duty to protect patrons from out‑of‑control motor vehicles and the limits of foreseeability, not with any duty to secure a ladder after express warnings. It focuses on whether the type of harm was reasonably foreseeable so as to create a duty at all, and concludes there was no such duty under the specific facts. It does not address or establish a standard of care regarding securing ladders, nor does it discuss conduct after explicit warnings by a plaintiff.
*See Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Sa.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner or proprietor is not an insurer of the safety of his patrons. ‘The test is “foreseeable harm.”… The underlying duty in every case, however, is to exercise the care which the circumstances reasonably require.’ Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341 Mass. 640, 642 (1961). Based on the evidence presented, there could be no reasonable difference of opinion as to the improbability of the incident which occurred.”

*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s property damage.
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass..case_name: Solimene v. B. GRAUEL & CO., KG
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass..support_reasoning: The case concerns personal injury from an allegedly defective machine and discusses negligence, design defect, proximate cause, and superseding cause in the context of bodily injury, not property damage. Although the opinion affirms that the defendant’s negligence was a proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries, it does not address property damage at all. Therefore, it cannot properly be cited as authority for the proposition that the defendant’s negligence was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s property damage.
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Generally, questions of causation, proximate and intervening, present issues for the jury to decide. … The judge left this issue to the jury. The jurors determined that any negligence of the employer was not a superseding cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. … The plaintiff has the burden to show that Grauel’s negligence caused her injury. … The plaintiff sustained her burden by proving that there was a greater probability that the harm which occurred was due to causes for which Grauel was responsible.”

*See Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 54.raw_text: *See Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 549 (1982) (damages recoverable when caused by negligent conduct).*
*See Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 54.proposition: Plaintiff’s resulting damages include repair costs, insurance deductible payments, and rental car expenses, totaling an amount to be proven at trial but reasonably expected to exceed $25,000.
*See Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 54.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the types of economic damages recoverable in a negligence case—repair costs, insurance deductibles, and rental car expenses—and the amount of such damages. Payton v. Abbott Labs deals with recovery for emotional distress and prenatal injury in DES litigation, and does not discuss property damage, repair costs, insurance deductibles, rental vehicles, or any analogous measure of consequential economic loss. Although it recognizes that damages are recoverable when caused by negligent conduct, it provides no specific authority for the particular categories of damages listed in the proposition.
*See Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 54.relevant_excerpt: “In summary, we hold that a plaintiff who alleges that she suffered injury in utero as a result of her mother's ingestion of a drug and that, but for the defendant's negligence, her mother would not have ingested that drug, has stated a claim upon which relief can be granted under Massachusetts law.”

*See G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85 (comparative.proposition: No fault or negligence on the part of Plaintiff contributed to the incident.

Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 56 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.proposition: Defendant’s conduct demonstrated a disregard for foreseeable risk equivalent to that found actionable under Massachusetts negligence jurisprudence.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: This dissenting opinion focuses on proximate cause and foreseeability, and repeatedly concludes that the plaintiff failed to prove that the defendants’ negligence caused the injury or that rape was within the scope of the foreseeable risk. It does not characterize the defendants’ conduct as demonstrating a disregard for foreseeable risk equivalent to actionable negligence; instead, it treats any alleged negligence as non-actionable because the risk of rape (given the gate and refectory conditions) was not foreseeable. The opinion thus undercuts, rather than supports, the claimed proposition.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff had the burden of proving ‘that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’ … The foreseeable risk of an inadequately secured gate is that an intruder might enter the premises for mischievous purposes. … Similarly, the jury would not have been warranted in finding that a prudent person in the defendants’ circumstances would have locked the refectory to prevent rape. Rape was not within the foreseeable risk of failure to lock the refectory.”

Afarian v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 449.raw_text: Afarian v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 449 Mass. 257, 261 (2007)
Afarian v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 449.proposition: Defendant’s conduct demonstrated a disregard for foreseeable risk equivalent to that found actionable under Massachusetts negligence jurisprudence.
Afarian v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 449.support_reasoning: The case does not find that the defendant’s conduct demonstrated disregard for a foreseeable risk; rather, it holds that the utility owed no duty because the drunk driver’s deviation from the roadway was not reasonably foreseeable under Massachusetts negligence principles. The court explicitly avoids deciding whether the pole’s placement created an unreasonable risk and instead concludes that imposing a duty in these circumstances would improperly approach strict liability. Thus, the opinion limits negligence liability instead of treating the defendant’s conduct as actionable disregard of a foreseeable risk.
Afarian v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 449.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that because he was intoxicated, Veilleux cannot be said to have deviated from the road in the ordinary course of travel and his deviation, which was caused by intoxication, was not, and could not have been, reasonably anticipated. Accordingly, the utility defendants owed no duty to Afarian. We therefore do not reach the question whether the pole’s placement created an unreasonable risk of harm to persons lawfully traveling on the road and to persons deviating from it in the ordinary course of travel.”

Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc., 401.raw_text: Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc., 401 Mass. 788, 790 (1988)
Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc., 401.proposition: Defendant’s conduct demonstrated a disregard for foreseeable risk equivalent to that found actionable under Massachusetts negligence jurisprudence.
Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc., 401.case_name: Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc.
Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc., 401.support_reasoning: The case squarely applies Massachusetts negligence principles to determine whether defendants’ failure to provide adequate security, in light of known criminal conditions, created a reasonably foreseeable risk of violent assault. The court affirms a jury verdict finding negligence and proximate cause, expressly holding that a stabbing of this type was within the reasonably foreseeable risks created by the defendants’ breach of duty. That reflects conduct showing disregard of foreseeable risk actionable under Massachusetts negligence law, consistent with the proposition.
Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc., 401.relevant_excerpt: “We have little hesitancy in ruling that the evidence warranted a finding that each defendant failed to fulfil its high duty of care concerning security in the terminal… There was evidence warranting a finding that the stabbing of Sharon was within the reasonably foreseeable risks created by each defendant’s breach of duty. The jury could have reasonably found that the defendants were negligent in failing to provide a uniformed security force in the terminal.”

*See Hebert v. Enos, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 8.raw_text: *See Hebert v. Enos, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 817, 818 (2004).*
*See Hebert v. Enos, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover compensatory damages under Massachusetts common law for the cost of repairs, rental car expenses, and any other consequential economic loss proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence.
*See Hebert v. Enos, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The opinion is a proximate-cause / foreseeability case about personal injuries from electric shock allegedly caused by negligent toilet repairs. It does not discuss the measure or categories of compensatory damages, nor recovery of repair costs, rental car expenses, or other consequential economic losses. The court ultimately affirms summary judgment for the defendant, so the case neither recognizes nor applies any rule about entitlement to such consequential economic damages under Massachusetts common law.
*See Hebert v. Enos, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: "Summary judgment is still appropriate, however, if a plaintiff has no reasonable expectation of proving that 'the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct.' ... We therefore conclude that Hebert’s severe and unfortunate injuries were the consequence of the type of unforeseeable accident for which we do not hold the defendant responsible in tort."

G.L. c. 261, \u00a7 1.proposition: Award costs of this action, including filing fees and other necessary expenses as permitted under G.L. c. 261, § 1;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award pre- and post-judgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B; and
